turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: You're giving your life away to become a goddamn statistic in U.S. Fucking A Today. That's got to be the least private thing I can think of.

turns.speaker: HEATHER MCNAMARA
turns.text: But what about Heather and Ram and Kurt?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: If everyone jumped off a bridge, young lady, would you?

turns.speaker: HEATHER MCNAMARA
turns.text: Probably....

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Hey now, if you were happy every day of your life, you wouldn't be a human being, you'd be a game show host.

turns.speaker: HEATHER MCNAMARA
turns.text: Let's knock off early. Go to the mall. Something lame like that.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: There are no stupid questions.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: If you inherit five million dollars the same day aliens tell the earth they're blowing us up in two days, what would you do?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: That's the stupidest question I've ever heard.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Probably just row on out to the middle of a lake. Bring along my sax, some tequila, and some Bach.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: How very.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: You going to pull a Big Gulp with that?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: No, but if you're nice I'll let you buy me a Slurpee. You know your 7-11speak pretty well.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: I've been moved around all my life; Dallas, Baton Rouge, Vegas, Sherwood Ohio, there's always a 7-11. Any town, any time, I can pop a Ham and Cheese in the microwave and feast on a Big Wheel. Keeps me sane.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Really? That thing in the caf today was pretty severe.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: The extreme always makes an impression, but you're right, it was severe. Did you say a Cherry or Coke Slurpee?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: I didn't. Cherry.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Just a humble perk from my Dad's Construction company or should I say Deconstruction company?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: I don't know. Should you?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: My father seems to enjoy tearing things down more than putting things up. Seen the commerical? "Bringing every State to a Higher State."

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Time out....Jason Dean. Your Pop's Fred Dean Construction. Must be rough. Moving place to place.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Everybody's life's got static. Is your life perfect?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Sure, I'm on my way to a party at Remington University.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: It's not perfect. I don't really like my friends.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: I don't really like your friends either.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: It's like they're just people I work with and our job is being popular and shit.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Maybe it's time for a vacation.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Dreadful etiquette. I apologize.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: S'okay....

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: I saw the croquet set-up in the back. Up for a match?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: That was my first game of Strip Croquet, you know. I thank you.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: You're welcome. It's a lot more interesting than just flinging off your clothes and boning away on the neighbor's swing set.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Now blah-blah-blah is all I do. I use my grand I.Q. to figure out what gloss to wear and how to hit three keggers before curfew. Some genius.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Heather Chandler is one bitch that deserves to die.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Killing her won't solve anything.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: A well-timed lightning bolt through her window and Monday morning, all the other heathers, shit, everybody would be cast fucking adrift.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Well then, I'll pray for rain.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: See the condoms in the grass over there. We killed tonight, Veronica. We murdered our baby.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Hey, it was good for me too, Sparky.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Just saying it's not hard to end a life.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: There's a big difference between the most popular girl in the school and dead sperm.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: I guess I don't know what the hell I'm talking about.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: I know exactly what the hell you're talking about and you're right, you don't know what the hell you're talking about. Let's just grow up, be adults, and die.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Good plan.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: But before that, I'd like to see Heather Chandler puke her guts out.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Trust me. She skips the Saturday morning trip to Grandma's even when she's not hungover.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Then let's just concoct ourselves a little hangover cure that'll induce her to spew red, white, and blue.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: I'm a Pine-Sol man, myself.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Don't be a dick. That stuff'll kill her.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: O-kay. We'll cook up some soup and put it in a Coke. Sick, eh? Now should it be Chicken-Noodle or Bean-with-Bacon?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Man Veronica, pull the plug on that shit. I say we go with Big Blue.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: What are you <u>doing</u>? You just can't go.....Besides, she'd never drink anything that looks like that.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Okay we'll use this. She won't be able to tell what she's drinking.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Milk and orange juice. Hmmmm. Maybe we could cough a phlegm globber in it or something.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Yeah, great.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: No luck? Well, milk and orange juice'll do quite nicely. Quite nicely.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Chick-en.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: You're not funny.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Something tells me you picked up the wrong cup.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: No shit, sherlock. I can't believe it. I just killed my best friend.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: And your worst enemy.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Same difference. Oh jesus, I'm gonna...

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: What are we going to tell the cops? "Fuck it if she can't take a joke, Sarge."

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Stop kidding around. I'm going to have to send my S.A.T. scores to San Quentin instead of Stanford.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: I'm just a little freaked, all right?  You got what you wanted, you know.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: It's one thing to want somebody out of your life. It's another thing to serve them a wake-up cup of Drano.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: We did a murder. In Ohio, that's a crime. But if this was like a suicide thing.....

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Like a suicide thing?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Adolescence is a period of life fraught with anxiety and confusion.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: I can do Heather's handwriting as well as my own.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: "You might think what I've done is shocking..."

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: "To me though, suicide is the natural answer to the myriad of problems life has given me."

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: That's good, but Heather would never use the word "myriad."

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: This is the last thing she'll ever write. She'll want to cash in on as many fifty-cent words as poss.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: She missed "myriad" on a vocab test two weeks ago, all right?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: That only proves my point more. The word is a badge for her failures at school.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: You're probably right..."People think just because you're beautiful and popular, life is easy and fun. Nobody understood I had feelings too."

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: "I die knowing no one knew the real me."

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: That's good. Have you done this before?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Mute!

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Next channel, darling.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Heather Chandler is more popular than ever now.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Yeah. Scary stuff.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Jason, why don't you ask your little friend to stay for dinner.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: My Mom's making my favorite meal tonight. Spaghetti. Lots of oregano.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Nice. The last time I saw my Mom, she was waving out the window of a library in Texas. Right, <u>Dad</u>?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: What is this shit?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: I'm doing a favor for Heather. A double date. I tried to tell you at the funeral but you rode off.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: So what? Don't smile like that, Jesus!

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Our love is God. Let's get a Slurpee.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: I don't get the point of me writing a suicide note when we'll just be shooting them with blanks.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Get crucial. We won't be using blanks this time.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: You can't be serious? Hey listen, my Bonnie-and-Clyde days are over.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Do you take German?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: French.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: These are Ich Luge bullets. My grandfather snared a shitload of them in W.W. Two. They're like tranquilizers only they break the surface of the skin, enough to cause blood, but not any real harm.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: So it looks like the person's been shot and killed when they're really just unconscious and bleeding.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: First tell me this similarity is not incredible.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Incredible similarity.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Ram and I died the day we realized we could never reveal our forbidden love to an uncaring and ununderstanding world. The joy we shared in each other's arms was greater than any touchdown. Yet we were forced to live the lie of Sexist- Beer Guzzling-Jock-Asshole.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Exquisite, but I don't think ununderstanding is a word.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: We don't want to make them out to be too secretly eloquent. Why would the Germans invent a bullet that doesn't kill people? I mean it <u>was</u> World War Two, not a school play.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: They used them on themselves to make it look like they were dead. Really quite a brilliant device, but too flamboyant to seriously produce.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Neat. Let's try it out on J.F.K.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: It doesn't work on small animals!

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Uh well hey, let's take a look at the homosexual artifacts I dug up. Now, prepare to be a little disappointed.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: We've got a Playgirl, a candy dish, a Joan Crawford post card, and lipstick.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: You must have had fun.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: You know it. Oh man, I almost forgot. The one perfecto thing I picked up...

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Perrier water!

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Oh come <u>on</u>. Lots of people drink Perrier. It's come a long way.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: This is Ohio. If you don't have a brewsky in your hand after dark you might as well be wearing a dress.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Oh, you're so smart. How about a little heterosexuality before we go?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Did you miss him completely?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Yeah, but don't worry, it was worth it just to see the look on....

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Don't move! I'll get him back!

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Kurt doesn't look too good.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Remember he's left-handed.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: We killed them, didn't we?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: You believed it because you wanted to believe it. Your true feelings were too gross and icky for you to face.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: I did not want them <u>dead</u>.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Did to.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Did not.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Did to.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Did not.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Football season's over, Veronica. Kurt and Ram had nothing to offer the school but date-rapes and A.I.D.S. jokes.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Sure. Can we make an ice run before the funeral?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Your son's dead and you love him.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: How do you think Mr. Kelly would react to a son with a limp wrist with a pulse?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Can't you see this is a special moment?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: I was just making it more special.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: You shoulda stuck around, jerk. Ms. Fleming wants to redefine the high school experience.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: She wants to ignore the high school experience. Our way's better. We scare people into not being assholes.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Don't <u>even</u> talk about that stuff!

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: You can be so immature!

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: You kids are making too much damn noise.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Let's just...settle down. Ms. Fleming has given us a chance to atone for...

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Our sins? What sins? If you put a Nazi in a concentration camp, does that make you a Nazi?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: May<u>be</u>.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: We're breaking up. I am out!

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Wha-at? Come on, there's another T.V. in the kitchen. You know you used to have a sense of humor.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: You're getting too cool for me, J.D. I don't know how to talk to you.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Our relationship's moving fast, I know, but I have real, real respect for you.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: I'm going to make this Ms. Pauline thing work. Lines of communication between the cliques. You were a phase....

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Phase my ass! You'll be <u>back</u>! I'm storming Normandy beaches and you're running in place with Pauline Fonda's airhead peacenik exercise program. Have to stay tough! You'll be back.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Catch a movie? Miniature Golf?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: I was thinking more along the lines of slitting Heather Duke's wrists open and making it look like a suicide.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: I could be up for that. I've already started underlining <u>meaningful</u> passages in Heather's copy of Catcher in the Rye, if you know what I mean. So are we on?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: It's over, J.D.  Over!

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: I don't get it! You were wrong! I was right! Strength, damnit! Come back!

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Get off my bed, you sick psycho! You think you're a rebel! You're not a rebel! You're a sick psycho! Do you think you're a rebel? Do you think you're a rebel? I wanna know!

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: "You say tomayto, I say tomahto. Let's call the whole thing off...Hold it!

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Look at that. Eskimo. One word. I love it. I usually go for whole sentences myself, but hey this is perfecto. Eskimo. So mysterious...

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Wait a....You're not listening! I'm not on your side....

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: You're still not listening! I'm not..

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Nag, nag, nag, nag. nag.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: This knife is filthy.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: What in the hell do you think I'm doing? Taking out her tonsils?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: I think I know Heather a bit better than you, okay? If she was going to slash her wrists, the knife would be absolutely spotless.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Tomorrow someone else will move into her place. That person could be me.  Ha, there's only one of us who knows Heather's handwriting and if you think I'm doing another suicide note.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: You don't get it, do you? Society nods its head at any horror the American teenager can think to bring upon itself. We don't need gloves and does anyone really care about exact handwriting?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: If you'll excuse me......

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: No-o!

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: I knew that loose was too noose! I mean, noose too loose! Goddamn you!

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Like father, like son. A serious-as- fuck bomb in the boiler room that'll set off a pack of thermals upstairs. Okay, so let's start by slowly putting the bomb down on the ground.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Okay, okay. I knew that. I knew that. Put your hands on your head.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: You didn't say Simon Says.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: It's all over, J.D. Help me to stop it.

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: You want to wipe the slate clean as much as I do. Okay, so maybe I am killing everyone in the school because nobody loves me. You have a purpose though! Remember? Let's face it, the only place different social types can genuinely get along with each other is in heaven.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: How do you turn the fucker off?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: You're not listening. People are going to look at the ashes of Westerburg and say there's a school that self-destructed not because society didn't care, but because that school <u>was</u> society. Is that deep or what? I'll let you put it in your diary, babe. Free of charge.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: The bomb, asshole!

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: Just push the red button twice. That's what stops it. If that's what you want, babe?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: You know what I want, babe?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: You really fucked me up, Veronica.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: I thought I...you..

turns.speaker: J.D.
turns.text: You've got power, Veronica. Power I didn't think you had. The slate is clean.

turns.speaker: RAM
turns.text: Who does that new kid think he is with that coat? Bo Diddley?

turns.speaker: KURT
turns.text: Veronica is into his act. No doubt.

turns.speaker: RAM
turns.text: Let's kick his ass.

turns.speaker: KURT
turns.text: Shit, we're seniors, Ram. Too old for that crap. Let's give him a scare though.

turns.speaker: RAM
turns.text: You going to eat this?

turns.speaker: KURT
turns.text: What did your <u>boyfriend</u> say when you told him you were moving to Sherwood, Ohio?

turns.speaker: RAM
turns.text: Answer him dick!

turns.speaker: KURT
turns.text: Hey Ram, doesn't this cafeteria have a No Fags Allowed Rule?

turns.speaker: KURT
turns.text: We on tonight man?

turns.speaker: RAM
turns.text: I still got to talk to Heather, dude. Weird funeral, huh?

turns.speaker: KURT
turns.text: Pretty weird.

turns.speaker: KURT
turns.text: That pudwapper just stepped on my foot.

turns.speaker: RAM
turns.text: Let's kick his ass.

turns.speaker: KURT
turns.text: Cool off, we're seniors.

turns.speaker: RAM
turns.text: Goddamn Geek!

turns.speaker: KURT
turns.text: Is it sleeping, dude?

turns.speaker: RAM
turns.text: I think so, man.

turns.speaker: KURT
turns.text: Then get over on my side. Oh shit, cowtipping is the fucking greatest.

turns.speaker: RAM
turns.text: Punch it in!

turns.speaker: RAM
turns.text: Sex and Drugs and HBO is all I ever need! Whoa! Can you hear me! Hello Tokyo! I said Sex and Drugs and...

turns.speaker: KURT
turns.text: Shut the fuck up, all right.

turns.speaker: RAM
turns.text: Lighten up, dude. In those woods is some of the finest pussy in the school and we don't even have to buy it a hamburger and a Diet Coke. Punch it in!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Hey kid, isn't the prom coming up?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: I guess.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Any contestants worth mentioning?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: May<u>be</u>. There's kind of a dark horse now in the running.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: You two....

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Great pate, but I'm going to have to motor if I want to be ready for the party tonight.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Terrible thing. So will we get to meet this dark horse prom contender?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: May<u>be</u>.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: You two....

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Greate pate, but I'm going to have to motor if I want to be ready for the funeral tomorrow.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: How was the funeral?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Superb.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Turn that back on!

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: This condescending junk makes suicide seem like a cool thing to do. Hey kids, make your parents and teachers feel like shit! Get the respect in death you'll never get in life.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Everybody cares for youth but nobody cares about Joey Blow. When that news reporter gets home he'll scream at his son for not mowing the lawn in the right pattern.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: I'm lost. You don't get enough attention, you get too much attention. Which is it? Where are your shoes?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: All we want is to be treated like human beings, not like guinea pigs to be experimented on and not like bunny rabbits to be patronized.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Dear Veronica, Heather was your soulmate.....Share.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Heather was cool, but cruel. The good looks and bad manners gave her power, but it could not give her happiness.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Everyone take their places on the stage!  Isn't this thrilling?!

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: But Ms. Fleming, it's just not right.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: What, the wine? I realize you're all under 21, but it seemed like such a perfect touch.  Could we get some more light up here?

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Veronica! J.D. told me you committed suicide last night!

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Where is he? Where's J.D.?

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: We have to talk.  Whether to kill yourself is one of the most important decisions a teenager has to make.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: Get a job.

turns.speaker: WHITNEY JAMES
turns.text: Heather Chandler, Kurt Kelly, and Rupert "Ram" Sweeney all had good looks and popularity, but there's one thing they didn't have: Values, Ambition, and Hope.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: That's three things.

turns.speaker: WHITNEY JAMES
turns.text: It rained everyday of my Maui vacation, but hey, I didn't kill myself. I'm Whitney James, Commentary.

turns.speaker: WHITNEY JAMES
turns.text: I got a confession to make. My name used to be Heather, too.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: But my name's not...

turns.speaker: WHITNEY JAMES
turns.text: People just don't take the name Heather seriously. They should, shouldn't they?

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: I'm so sorry. I was led to believe there were going to be different kinds of social and psychological types at this gathering.

turns.speaker: WHITNEY JAMES
turns.text: Oh, I was scared of the same thing, Heather. The minute you try to deal with the actual teenagers who have contemplated suicide you're stepping into quicksand. Quicksand filled with bad complexions, bad grades, bad parents, bad drugs, and all sorts of doody nobody wants to hear let alone bend down to clean up.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: The world wants winners, I guess. Not people stained with loserness.

turns.speaker: WHITNEY JAMES
turns.text: Stained with loserness. Oh, I like it. Can I use that. It'd be dynamite on interoffice memoranda.

turns.speaker: VERONICA
turns.text: It's all yours, Heather. Now if you'll excuse me, I'm going to go throw up.

turns.speaker: WHITNEY JAMES
turns.text: Sure. Ciao.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Mummy has a special technique called "Deep Therapy."

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: I'm not sure . . . but it's proving to be very popular!

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: I adore anything to do with the arts.

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: We're pretty handy with model making, too, eh?

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: I've never cottoned on to Plasticine like you girls, but I enjoy making things out of wood.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Are you a carpenter, Mr. Rieper? HERBERT shakes his head.

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: I work at Dennis Brothers Fish Supply.

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: This story of yours-maybe the school newspaper will print it when it's finished.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Actually, Mr. Rieper . . . it's a novel, and we'll be sending it to New York. That's where all the big publishing houses are based.

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: Is that a fact! You'd better put me name down for an advance copy!

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: Let's have 'em now, while they're fresh, eh, Nora?

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: playfully shoves his hand away.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: I'll think you'll find our Mr. Bayliss is not keen on seafood. I've got lamb chops in the 'frigerator.

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: sighs as HONORA puts the frying pan on the stove.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: Come on! Sausage rolls.

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: Come on through.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: and Pauline hurriedly work together, setting out plates and cutlery.

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: Look who I've found!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: whips off her pinny as HERBERT leads Juliet into the dining room.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: I've booked you in for a chest X-ray . . . just to be on the safe side.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: pops a couple more potatoes on Pauline's plate. HERBERT glances at Pauline.

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: Thought I'd have a go at building the birdhouse on Saturday . . . anyone want to give me a hand?

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: Yvonne hasn't been herself, either. Locking herself away in her room . . . endlessly writing.

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: sits down next to Honora, glass of sherry in hand.

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: No arguments there, Dr. Hulme! All that time inside working on those novels of theirs. They don't get fresh air or exercise!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: frowns at Henry.

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: waves a pair of new socks around. The family laughing and talking. Pauline is not participating. She is leaning back, looking morose. HONORA looks at her with concern.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: Is it hurting, dear?

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: is chopping firewood in the back garden. HONORA approaches him.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: I've just had Hilda Hulme on the phone.

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: What now?

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: She says Juliet's in a terrible state . . .

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: accompanies Hilda into the hallway.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: breaks down into heavy sobs.

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: I'd better be getting back. Bye, love.

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: pulls his coat on. HONORA gives him a peck cheek.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: Bye.

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: Have a nice outing, you lot.

turns.speaker: HERBERT
turns.text: wanders out. HONORA turns to Pauline and Juliet.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: Well . . . I better make myself a bit more presentable.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Hello!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: Well? Tell us! How'd it go?

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Got an A, Mum!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: glows with pride. STEVE is emptying his pockets on the bench. HONORA pats STEVE's hand.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: He's the manager!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: leads a young man-JOHN-into the dining room.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I spent a wretched night. It would be wonderful if I could get tuberculosis, too.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: comes in with a breakfast tray: bacon and eggs, tea and toast.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: Come on, sit up.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I'm not hungry.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: You've got to eat, Yvonne. You hardly touched our dinner. I'm not having you falling ill.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I just want to be on my own for a while.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: starts to cut up a slice of bacon and offers it to Pauline.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: You may have forgotten that you were once a very sick little girl, but I haven't!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: holds up a loaded fork. Pauline reluctantly takes it.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Do you think Juliet could stay here while her parents are away?

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: Juliet's infectious . . . she'll be going to hospital.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: But she'll have no one to look after her!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: Her parents won't be going overseas now . . . they'll have to cancel their trip. Don't worry about Juliet.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I had a nasty foreboding feeling at first, but now I realise my crime was too frightful for an ordinary lecture.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: From now on, you're sleeping in the house, where we can keep an eye on you.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: If you think for one minute that your father and I will tolerate this sort of behaviour, you've got another thing coming! You're only 14!!! You're a child! What on earth's the matter with you, Yvonne? You know what can happen with boys . . . Don't you have any self-respect?

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: sighs.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Can I go now?

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: grabs Pauline by the shoulders.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: My God, what a disgrace you are! You shame me, you shame the family. You're nothing but a cheap little tart!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Well, I guess I take after you then!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: whirls around and slaps Pauline on the cheek.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: You ran off with Dad when you were only 17! Nana Parker told me!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: steps back.
